{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}}{{Use British English|date=October 2018}} '''Colloquial Welsh prepositions''' deals with the [[preposition]]s (Welsh: {{lang|cy|arddodiad}}) of the [[Colloquial Welsh morphology|colloquial Welsh language]], the spoken [[language register|register]] of the modern [[Welsh language]] as spoken in [[Wales]] by [[first-language]] speakers. This page does not deal with the literary standard forms of the prepositions nor any dialect which may have arisen outside of Wales. Welsh has two standardised forms: ''Literary Welsh'' – a conservative language reserved for literary purposes which retains some features of older Welsh; and ''Colloquial Welsh'' – the Welsh one will hear being spoken in Welsh speaking areas. For the most part the two languages share prepositions, though for some of them their usages can differ; there are also some which have lost their inflected forms in the colloquial language but is preserved in the literary standard. Colloquial Welsh also shows some variation in initial-consonant mutations, which is explained below, while the literary form retains the "proper" mutations in all cases. Welsh prepositions do (for the most part) perform the same rolls as English prepositions but there is variation and these must be learnt as they are encountered. For instance it is often taught that Welsh ''am'' "means 'for'" and ''i'' "means 'to'"; this is not incorrect but ''am'' can also mean 'about' or 'at' and ''i'' can mean 'for'. The usages given below outline how each preposition is used in modern colloquial Welsh. ==Definitions of Welsh prepositions== Prepositions are words like [[List of English prepositions|''on, at, to, from, by'' and ''for'' in English]].{{cite book |last=King |first=Gareth |year=2016 |orig-year=1993 |chapter=443-476 Prepositions |title=Modern Welsh – A Comprehensive Grammar |language=English |edition=Third |location=London and New York |publisher=Routledge |pages=335-373 |isbn=978-1-138-82630-4}} They often describe a relationship, spatial or temporal, between persons and objects. For example, 'the book is ''on'' the table'; 'the table is ''by'' the window'. Welsh prepositions come in two categories: ''simple prepositions ({{lang|cy|arddodiad godidog}})'' and ''compound prepositions ({{lang|cy|arddodiad cyfansawdd}})''; the former are single words, like English ''on, at, from, to'' etc. while the latter consist of a simple preposition + some other element (often a noun) like English ''in front of'' or ''in addition to''. Compound prepositions are less frequent than simple prepositions and are discussed below. ==Simple prepositions== There are approximately two-dozen or so simple prepositions in modern colloquial Welsh. While some have clear-cut and obvious translations (''heb'' ‘without’), others correspond to different English prepositions depending on context (''i, wrth, am''). As with all areas of modern Welsh, some words are preferred in the North and others in the South. The main prepositions used in modern colloquial Welsh are (alternative forms in parentheses): {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * â / ag * am * ar * at * cyn * dan (o dan) * dros (tros) * efo (hefo) * gan * ger * gyda / gydag * heb * hyd {{col-2}} * i * mewn * o * oddiar (oddi ar) * oddiwrth (oddi wrth) * rhag * rhwng * tan * trwy (drwy) * tua / tuag * wrth * yn {{col-end}} Most of these (but not all) share the following characteristics: # they cause mutation of the following word # they inflect for person and number, similar to verbs # they can be used with a following verbal-noun ==Mutations after prepositions== The majority of Welsh prepositions cause mutation to the following word – the most common, by far, is the soft mutation. Examples: {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * ''am ddim'' – ‘for nothing, free’ (< ''dim'') * ''dan ofal'' – ‘under care’ (< ''gofal'') * ''i Dreffynnon'' – ‘to [[Holywell, Flintshire|Holywell]]’ (< ''Treffynnon'') {{col-2}} * ''ar fwrdd'' – ‘on a table’ (< ''bwrdd'') * ''heb fynd'' – ‘without going’ ( < ''mynd'') * ''o gig'' – ‘of meat’ (< ''cig'') {{col-end}} Several do not cause any mutation (most notably ''rhag, rhwng'' and ''mewn''), while ''â, gyda'' and ''tua'' should cause aspirate mutation but in reality they are usually left unmutated (except for set expressions), since the aspirate mutation is dying out and for many speakers only mutation of ''c-'' /k/ is normal while mutation of ''p-'' /p/ and ''t-'' /t/ is not. ''Yn'' ‘in’ alone causes the nasal mutation which also is not as widespread as suggested by the literary standard and is often replaced by the soft mutation. It should also be noted that personal names are not mutated after prepositions but names of places and other nouns are: ''i ferch'' ‘to a girl’, ''o Fangor'' ‘from Bangor’, but ''i Dafydd'' ‘to Dafydd’, not ''*i Ddafydd'' (although mutation of personal names can be found in older texts). ==Inflected prepositions== When used with a personal pronoun, most prepositions insert a linking syllable before the pronoun. This syllable changes for each preposition and results in an inflection pattern similar to that found in Welsh verbs. Broadly speaking, the endings for inflected prepositions ({{lang|cy|arddodiad rhagenwol}}) are as follows: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|-a i}} | {{lang|cy|-on ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|-at ti}} | {{lang|cy|-och chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|-o fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|-yn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|-i hi}} |} There is some dialect variation between these endings, particularly with 1st and 2nd pers. sing., which can often end in ''-o i'' and ''-ot ti'' and 2nd pers. pl. ''-och chi'' is often heard as ''-ach chi''. 3rd pers. sing. and 3rd pers. pl. endings are always as shown but almost always omit the pronoun element, leaving the inflectional ending by itself to indicate person: * ''Gad lonydd iddo!'' – ‘Leave him alone!’ (instead of ''Gad lonydd iddo fe'') * ''Na i hala llythyr ati bore fory'' – ‘I’ll send her a letter tomorrow morning’ (instead of ''… ati hi…'') * ''Paid deud wrtho am y tro'' – ‘Don’t tell him for the time being’ (instead of ''…wrtho fo…'') But note that the 3rd pers. pl. ''-yn nhw'' is never shortened in this manner. These differ from the literary standard where the 1st pers. sing. is ''-af i''; the 1st pers. pl. is ''-om ni''; the 3rd pers. sing. masc. is ''-o ef'' and the 3rd. pers. pl. is ''-ynt hwy''. The literary standard also has the alternative 2nd pers. pl. pronoun ''chwi''. Most of these are never encountered in the colloquial language and therefore will not be presented in the inflected forms in this article. The linking element between the preposition and the ending is more complicated, however. Different prepositions use a different linking element. For example, ''am'' inserts ''-dan-'' before its endings (''amdana i, amdanat ti, amdani hi'' etc.), while ''heb'' uses ''-dd-'' (''hebdda i, hebddo fo, hebddyn nhw'' etc.) ''Rhwng'' changes its vowel (from ''w'' to ''y'') as well as inserting ''-dd-'' (''rhyngddyn nhw'') while some, like ''at'' and ''wrth'' add the endings with no linking element (''ato fe, atoch chi, wrthyn nhw, wrthon ni'' etc.) and some, like ''gyda'' and ''efo'' do not inflect at all. ==Prepositions and their uses== ===Â / ag=== ''Â'' (''ag'' before vowels) causes aspirate mutation. It means ‘with’, but note that there are other equivalents to ‘with’ in Welsh (''efo, gan'' and ''gyda'') Use of ''â/ag'' is fairly restricted: # It indicates the means by which something is done or achieved, or the instrument of an action: ## ''Nes i agor ‘y mys i â chyllell fara'' – ‘I cut [literally ‘opened’] my finger with a breadknife’
This usage often uses ‘by’ in English as an alternative to ‘with’: ##
  • ''Gawn ni dalu â siec fan hyn?'' – ‘Can we pay by cheque here?’ #
  • Where the relationship between two objects is regarded as a close and permanent association, ''â/ag'' is more common than ''gyda'' or ''efo''. # It means ‘as’ with equative forms of adjectives: ## ''Mor ddu â’r fran'' – ‘As black as a crow’’ # Used idiomatically with the verbs ''mynd'' and ''dod'' to create ''mynd â'' ‘take’ and ''dod â'' ‘bring’ [literally ‘go with’ and ‘come with’]. The Welsh word ''cymryd'' 'take' strictly means 'take hold of, seize, grab' and cannot be used in place of ''mynd â''. # ''Â/ag'' is used with many common verbs like ''siarad'' 'speak', ''cwrdd'' 'meet' and ''ymweld'' 'visit' to make ''siarad â, cwrdd â'' and ''ymweld â'' in which case Welsh aligns more with [[American English]] than with [[British English]]: ## ''Dim ond ddoe o'n i'n siarad ag e'' – 'It was only yesterday I was speaking to him' [...speaking with him] ## ''Lle gwrddest ti â fe gynta?'' – 'Where did you first meet him?' [...meet with him?] ## ''Pa mor aml dach chi'n ymweld â'ch nain yn y Gogledd?'' – 'How often do you visit your grandmother up North?' [...visit with your grandmother...] # The verb ''peidio'' 'stop, cease' is used to form negative commands and is followed by ''â/ag'' in the standard language but its use is entirely optional in speech. with the exception of certain set phrases, e.g. ''paid â malu'' 'stop talking nonsense'. In the colloquial language both ''paid â phoeni'' [or ''paid â poeni'' without mutation] and ''paid poeni'' are commonly heard. ===Am=== ''Am'' is a very common preposition in spoken Welsh with a range of English equivalents: #'Exchange for' – this meaning is used with verbs like ''talu'' 'pay' to give '' talu am'' 'pay for' [give money in exchange for]: ## ''Dales i bedair punt am y rhain'' – 'I paid four pounds [£4] for these' # In time expressions Welsh ''am'' is equivalent to English 'at': ##''Ddo i'n ôl am saith'' – 'I'll come back at seven'
    # ''Am'' means 'for' in expressions of duration of time: ## ''Fuon nhw yng Ngogledd yr Eidal am fis'' – 'They were in Northern Italy for a month' # ''Am'' means 'about/concerning' when used with the verbs ''siarad'' 'speak/talk', ''sôn'' 'speak/talk' and ''meddwl'' 'think': ## ''Am beth dych chi'n siarad?'' – 'What are you talking about?' ## ''Gawn ni weld be' mae'n feddwl am hynny'' – 'We will see what s/he thinks about that' # Spatially, ''am'' means 'about/around' with a sense of something actually being surrounded or enclosed: ## ''Rhowch rwymyn am ei ben o'' – 'Put a bandage around his head'
    Phrases like 'around the town' require a compound preposition like ''o amgylch'' or ''o gwmpas''. # When ''am'' precedes a verbal-noun it means '... want to...': ## ''Wyt ti am ddod 'da ni neu beidio, 'te?'' – 'Do you want to come with us or not, then?' ## ''Dw i am siarad ag e cyn iddo fynd'' – 'I want to talk to him before he goes' Using ''am'' to mean 'about' with verbs have been discussed above. With most other verbs ''am'' usually means 'for': * ''Dw i wedi bod yn chwilio amdanat ti ers awr'' – 'I have been looking for you for an hour' ''Am'' also has other meanings in the [[Literary Welsh morphology|literary language]] which are not a feature of the spoken form, such as 'towards'.{{cite book |last=Thomas |first=Stephen J. |year=1980 |orig-year=1980 |chapter=Prepositions |title=A Welsh Grammar |language=English |edition=First |location=Cardiff |publisher=[[University of Wales|University of Wales Press]] |pages=127-143 |isbn=0-7083-0737-X}} '''Inflected forms of ''am''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''am'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|amdana i}} | {{lang|cy|amdanon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|amdanat ti}} | {{lang|cy|amdanoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|amdano fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|amdanyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|amdani hi}} |} ===Ar=== ''Ar'' has a number of English equivalents, but usually equates to 'on'. # ''Ar'' means 'on' in a purely spatial sense with location and motion: ## ''Mae'r llyfr ar y bwrdd'' – 'The book is on the table' ## ''Rho'r llyfr ar y bwrdd'' – 'Put the book on the table' # It means 'about to' when followed by a verbal-noun: ## ''Brysiwch, mae'r trên ar fynd!'' – 'Hurry up, the train's about to go!' ## ''Mae teledu lloeren ar ddod'' – 'Satellite TV is almost here' [literally 'about to come'] ## ''Pan o'n i ar wneud hynny'' – 'When I was about to do that' # ''Ar'' is used with expressions of temporary physical and mental states, like illnesses. It often (but not always) corresponds to English 'have': ## ''Mae'r ddannodd arna i'' – 'I've got toothache [literally 'toothache is on me'] ## ''Roedd y ffliw arni'' – 'She had flu' [lit. 'the flu was on her'] ## ''Oes ofn arnat ti?'' – 'Are you afraid?' [lit. 'is fear on you?] # ''Ar'' can mean 'of' when talking about a part or sample: ## ''Dim ond rhyw flas ges i arno fo'' – 'I only got a taste of it' # ''Ar'' is often used with expressions of time and the weather where its English equivalent can change: ## ''ar Ddydd Llun'' – 'on a Monday, on Mondays' ## ''ar yr un adeg'' – 'at the same time' ## ''ar dywydd poeth'' – 'in hot weather' # ''Ar'' is used with the verbs ''gwrando'' 'listen' and ''edrych'' 'look' to make ''gwrando ar'' 'listen to' and ''edrych ar'' 'watch'. A common mistake made by learners is to use the preposition ''i'' : ## ''Ar beth dych chi'n gwrando?'' – 'What are you listening to?' ## ''Ar beth wyt ti'n edrych?'' – 'What are you watching?' ## ''Dw i'n edrych ar y teledu'' – 'I'm watching TV' '''Inflected forms of ''ar''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''ar'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|arna i}} | {{lang|cy|arnon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|arnat ti}} | {{lang|cy|arnoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|arno fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|arnyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|arni hi}} |} ===At=== While Welsh ''at'' often corresponds to English 'at', the field of scope of Welsh ''at'' is far wider. # ''At'' is used for English 'to' when it implies motion ''up to'' (but not ''into'') a destination (''into'' is covered by ''i'' and the two are often confused by English speakers). In Welsh we must say, for example, ''danfon llythyr at Sioned'' 'send a letter to Sioned' but ''danfon llythyr i Lundain'' 'send a letter to London' – Sioned is a person and takes ''at'', London is a place and takes ''i''. More examples: ## ''Rhaid ini fynd â ti at y deintydd bore fory'' – 'We must take you to the dentist tomorrow morning' ## ''Lluchiwch y bêl ata i!'' – 'Chuck the ball to me!' #It can mean 'for' with the sense of 'benefit/good/purpose of': ## ''At beth mae hwnna i fod?'' – 'What's that supposed to be for? ## ''Mae'r arian i gyd yn mynd at achosion da'' – 'All the money is going to(wards) good causes' # ''Tuag at'' is the usual expression corresponding to the literary term ''tua'' 'towards'. In the colloquial language ''tua'' now means 'about' in expressions of time. ## ''Rhedwch chi i gyd tuag ata i!'' – 'All of you run towards me!' # ''Hyd at'' is a variant of ''hyd'' 'up to': ## ''Dyma hi wedyn yn cochi hyd at ei chlustiau'' – 'Then she blushed right up to her ears Some verbs which use ''at'' include: * ''anelu at'' – 'aim for/at' * ''anfon/danfon at'' – 'send to (a person)' * ''cofio at'' – 'remember (a person to another person)' * ''cyfeirio at'' – 'refer to' * ''cyfrannu at'' – 'contribute to' * ''dychryn at'' – 'be frightened at' * ''edrych ymlaen at'' - 'look forward to' * ''hala at'' – 'send to (a person)' * ''paratoi at'' – 'prepare for' * ''(y)sgrifennu/sgwennu at'' – 'write to (a person)' * ''synnu at'' – 'be surprised at, marvel at' * ''ychwanegu at'' – 'add to' '''Inflected forms of ''at''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''at'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|ata i}} | {{lang|cy|aton ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|atat ti}} | {{lang|cy|atoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|ato fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|atyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|ati hi}} |} ===Cyn=== ''Cyn'' means 'before' in expressions of time, never in spatial expressions, e.g. ''cyn y Rhyfel'' 'before the War' or ''cyn deg o'r gloch'' 'before 10 o'clock'. It is also used as a conjunction. ''Cyn'' does not cause a mutation, nor does it have inflected forms. Examples of ''cyn'': * ''Mi ddaw hi'n ôl cyn hynny'' – 'She'll come back before that' * ''Gadewch ini orffen hwn cyn y bore'' – 'Let's get this finished before the morning' It is important for anyone learning Welsh to understand that the compound preposition ''o flaen'' 'in front of' cannot be used instead of ''cyn''. The two are not interchangeable despite their interchangeability in English in sentences like 'to stand before/in front of the building': * ''Na i gwrdd â chi cyn y cyngerdd'' – 'I'll meet you before the concert' [temporal] * ''Na i gwrdd â chi o flaen Canolfan y Celfyddydau'' – 'I'll meet you in front of the Arts Centre' [spatial] As an adjectival prefix, ''cyn-'' always means 'ex-' or 'former'. ===Dan=== ''Dan'' (sometimes heard as ''o dan'') causes soft mutation and means 'under': ''dan y dŵr'' 'under the water', ''dan ddylanwad ei reini'' 'under the influence of his parents'. It should be noted that the related compound preposition ''oddidan'' (also ''odditan'') means 'from under'. The term ''dan ofal'' 'under care', abbreviated to ''d/o'' is the norm for 'care of' when addressing letters. The two most important idioms using ''dan'' are: # ''Dan ei sang'' – 'full to bursting, packed' (used of rooms, buildings, etc.) # ''Dan haul'' – 'under (the) sun' The unmutated form, ''tan'' is now, to all intents and purposes, obsolete in this meaning and has become a separate preposition in its own right and means 'until'. '''Inflected forms of ''dan''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''dan'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|dana i}} | {{lang|cy|danon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|danat ti}} | {{lang|cy|danoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|dano fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|danyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|dani hi}} |} ===Dros=== ''Dros'' has two variants: ''tros'' (regarded as particularly literary nowadays) and ''drost'' (still very common in speech all over Wales). ''Dros'' causes soft mutation and means: # 'Over' in a purely spatial sense. For example, ''dros y bont'' 'over the bridge', ''edrych dros y clawdd'' 'look over the hedge'. It can also mean 'all over' when speaking about a large area: ''Mae caneuon Meinir Gwilym yn boblogaidd dros Gymru gyfan'' 'Meinir Gwilym's songs are popular all over Wales'. #'Over' in the sense of 'more than' (as in English): ''Mae dros fil o bobol yn y neuadd yn barod'' 'There are over a thousand people in the hall already'. # 'For' in the sense of 'on behalf of': ## ''Nei di fynd lawr i'r siop drosta i?'' – 'Will you go to the shop for me?' ## ''Dan ni i gyd yn teimlo drostat ti'' – 'We all feel for you'' # When used with nouns like ''rheswm'' 'reason' and ''esgus'' 'excuse' (and usually with a verbal-noun) equates to English 'for': ## ''Alla i'm gweld unrhyw reswm dros ymddwyn fel 'ny'' – 'I can see no reason for behaving like this' ## ''Barn Huw ydy fod 'na ddim esgus dros ragrith'' – 'Huw is of the opinion that there is no excuse for hypocrisy' Idioms using ''dros'' tend to be adverbial. Two very common and useful set phrases using ''dros'' are: # ''Dros ben llestri'' – 'Over the top' ## '''Sdim eisiau mynd dros ben llestri, nag oes?'' – 'There's no need to go over the top, is there?' # ''Dros ben'' – 'Exceedingly' ## ''Mae'r sefyllfa yn un ddifrifiol dros ben'' – 'The situation is (an) exceedingly serious (one)' '''Inflected forms of ''dros''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''dros'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|drosta i}} | {{lang|cy|droston ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|drostat ti}} | {{lang|cy|drostoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|drosto fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|drostyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|drosti hi}} |} ===Efo=== ''Efo'' (also ''hefo'' in some areas of North Wales) does not cause mutation and is a general word meaning 'with' and is restricted to Northern dialects of the spoken language. In the South ''gyda'' is always used instead. The only appearance of ''gyda'' in the North is in set phrases like ''gyda'r nos'' 'in the evening'. ''Efo'' and ''gyda'' are not, however, always interchangeable as ''gyda'' (or its contracted form '''da'') is used in the South to express possession; in the North this is not achieved by ''efo'' but by ''gan''. The following examples are all Northern dialect where ''(h)efo'' can be substituted for ''gyda'' in the South: # ''Dan ni'n mynd i'r Swisdir efo'r Jonesiaid eleni'' – 'We are going to Switzerland with the Jonses this year' # ''Hefo pwy dach chi'n rhannu tro 'ma, 'ta?'' – 'Who are you sharing with this time, then?' # ''Mi ddo i hefo chdi rŵan'' – 'I'll come with you now' ''Efo'' does not have inflected forms. ===Gan=== ''Gan'' (often heard as ''gyn'') causes soft mutation. It is another Northern dialect word used to express possession and is replaced by ''gyda'' in the South. ''Mae gan Mrs Williams gath fawr'' 'Mrs Williams has a large cat'. Although ''gan'' and ''gyda'' are interchangeable in this context, the structure of the sentences differs and it is not as simple as substituting one word for the other. The following example sentence is translated using ''gan'' (Northern) and ''gyda'' (Southern) and means 'do you have enough money?': # ''Oes gen ti ddigon o arian?'' (Northern) # ''Oes digon o arian gyda ti?'' (Southern) There are, however, other uses for ''gan'' not involving possession and are therefore common in both the North and the South: # 'by' in passive sentences ## ''Fe geith copïau o'r llyfr eu harwyddo gan yr awdur bore fory'' – 'Copies of the book will be signed by the author tomorrow morning' ## ''Ges i mrathu gan gi ar y ffordd adre'' – 'I got bitten by a dog on the way home' # By extension of 1 (above) it is also used to mean 'by' as in the author of a work: ## ''The Lord of the Rings gan J. R. R. Tolkien'' # Equates to English 'from' or 'off' where something is handed over or transmitted from one thing to another: (Compare with ''oddiwrth'') ## ''Ges i bunt gynno fo'' – ''I got a pound off him' ## ''Pa newyddion gaethon nhw gynni hi?'' – 'What news did they get from her?' ## ''Gyn bwy gest ti fenthyg ono fo?'' – 'Who did you borrow it from?' # When used with verbal-nouns ''gan'' can imply a simultaneous action: ## ''Aethon nhw lawr y stryd gan guro ar y drysiau i gyd'' – 'They went down the street banging on all the doors' ## ''Gan feddwl, dw i ddim yn siwr fyddai hynny'n syniad da'' – 'Thinking about it, I'm not sure (if) that would be a good idea'
    In this sense the pronunciation is usually ''gan'' and not ''gyn''. Some common idioms using ''gan'': # ''Mae'n ddrwg gen i'' – 'I'm sorry' # ''(Mae'n) well gen i'' – 'I prefer' (c.f. ''well imi...'' 'I had better...') # ''Mae'n dda gen i gwrdd â chi'' – 'I'm pleased to meet you' '''Inflected forms of ''gan''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''gan'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|gen i, gyn i}} | {{lang|cy|gynnon ni, ganddon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|gen ti, gyn ti}} | {{lang|cy|gynnoch chi, gennoch chi, ganddoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|gynno fe/fo, ganddo fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|gennyn nhw, ganddyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|gynni hi, ganddi hi}} |} ===Ger=== ''Ger'' does not cause a mutation and is used with geographical locations (usually town and city names) to mean 'in the vicinity of': # ''Ger Barcelona mae Mark a'i deulu'n byw bellach'' – 'Mark and his family live near Barcelona now' # ''Dan ni'n byw mewn pentre bach ger Harlech'' – 'We live in a small village near Harlech' It should be noted that ''ger'' is related to the term ''gerbron'' which means 'before' in the sense of 'in the presence of' or 'for the attention of' and is used with nouns like ''llys'' 'court' or ''bwrdd'' 'board': # ''Daethpwyd â chwe achos gerbron y llys bore 'ma'' – 'Six cases were brought before the court this morning' [formal] # ''Bydd y bwrdd yn rhoi ystyriaeth fanwl i'r holl dystiolaeth a roddwyd gerbron yr wythnos hon'' – 'The board will carefully consider all the evidence that has been presented this week' [formal] ''Ger'' has no inflected forms. ===Gyda / gydag=== ''Gyda'' (''gydag'' before vowels) causes aspirate mutation and is the general term for 'with' in the South (c.f. ''efo'' in the North). With the exception of idioms, it is usually heard as '''da'' in speech: ''Oes amser 'da chi i brynu'r tocynnau?'' 'Have you got time to buy the tickets?' ''Gyda/gydag'' is used in the South to show possession, as ''gan'' is used in the North, but their forms differ, compare the following sentence 'do you have enough food?': # ''Oes digon o fwyd 'da ti?'' (South) # ''Oes gen ti ddigon o fwyd?'' (North) ''Gyda/gydag'' does not have inflected forms, so ''gyda fi, gyda ti, gyda nhw'' but note that 'with him' can be either ''(gy)da fe'' or ''(gy)dag e''. ===Heb=== ''Heb'' causes soft mutation and in its primary meaning, ''heb'' means 'without': ''heb arian'' 'without money', ''peidiwch mynd hebdda i!'' 'don't go without me!'. ''Heb'' can be used with a verbal-noun to make a negative construction in the perfect tense – equivalent to ''ddim wedi'': ''Dan ni heb benderfynu'' 'We haven't decided' (=''Dan ni ddim wedi penderfynu''); ''Mae o heb fynd eto'' 'He hasn't gone yet' (=''Dydy o ddim wedi mynd eto''). ''Heb'' + possessive adjective + verbal-noun corresponds to 'which/who has/have not been' or an adjectival 'un....ed': ''pobol heb eu cofrestru'' 'people who have not been registered' [lit. 'people without their registering']; ''pryd o fwyd heb ei fwyta'' 'an uneaten meal' [lit. 'a meal of food without its eating']. Some idioms using ''heb'': # ''Heb ei ail'' (feminine: ''heb ei hail'') – 'second-to-none, first-rate' ## ''Dyma bortread heb ei ail o fywyd y glowyr yn y tridegau'' – This is a first-rate portrayal of miners' lives in the thirties' # ''Yn amlach na heb'' or ''yn fyw na heb'' – 'more often than not' ## ''Yn amlach na heb, mae'r fath ymddygiad yn arwain at drychineb'' – 'More often than not, this kind of behaviour leads to disaster' '''Inflected forms of ''heb''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''heb'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|hebdda i}} | {{lang|cy|hebddon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|hebddat ti}} | {{lang|cy|hebddoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|hebddo fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|hebddyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|hebddi hi}} |} ===Hyd=== ''Hyd'' causes soft mutation and has the following meanings: # 'up to, until' in a temporal sense. In this sense it is often interchangeable with ''tan''. ## ''Mae'r cyrsiau'n para hyd ddiwedd mis Mehefin'' – 'The courses go on until the end of June' # 'up to' in a spatial sense and is often expanded to ''hyd at'': ## ''Oedd e hyd at ei wddw yn y dŵr'' – 'He was up to his neck in the water' ## ''Wedson nhw 'tha i am dalu hyd at ugain punt a dim mwy'' – 'I was told to pay up to twenty pounds (£20) and no more' Pronouns are not normally used with this preposition. The following are all commonly used idioms using ''hyd'', though it is not strictly a preposition in all cases: # ''Cael hyd i'' – 'find' ## ''Gest ti hyd iddo?'' – 'Did you find it?' # ''Dod o hyd i'' – 'find' ## ''Daethpwyd o hyd i gorff'' – 'A body has been found' [formal] # ''Hyd yn oed'' – 'even' ## ''Mae hyd yn oed Gareth wedi dod'' – 'Even Gareth has come' # ''Hyd yn hyn'' (or ''hyd yma'') – 'so far, up till now' ## '''Sdim sôn am fynd at y llysoedd hyd yn hyn'' – 'There's no talk of going to the courts so far' # ''O hyd'' – 'still; all the time' ## ''Dyn ni yma o hyd'' – 'We're still here' ## ''Mae o'n siarad o hyd am ei ffôn symudol'' – 'He's always going on about his mobile phone' # ''Hyd y gwela i'' – 'as far as I can see' ## ''Fydd 'na ddim problemau hyd y gwela i'' – 'There'll be no problems as far as I can see' # ''hyd y gwn i'' – 'as far as I know' ## ''Mae popeth wedi'i drefnu, hyd y gwn i'' – 'Everything's set, as far as I know' # ''Hyd'' also appears as a conjunction meaning 'until' with a following verb ## ''Ewch ymlaen ffordd 'ma hyd gwelwch chi faes chwarae ar y dde'' – 'Go on this way until you see you see a playing field on the right' # The compound preposition ''ar hyd'' 'along, the length of...' and with units of time 'all....... long' ## ''Ewch ar hyd y ffordd 'ma am ddeng munud, yna trowch i'r dde'' – 'Go along this road for ten minutes, then turn left' ## ''Ar hyd y nos'' – 'All night long' ''Hyd'' does not have inflected forms. ===I=== ''I'' causes soft mutation and often, but by no means always, corresponds to English 'to'. It is possibly the most frequently used preposition in the spoken Welsh language. ''I'' corresponds to English 'to' in the following senses: # Motion towards or into a place ## ''Dych chi'n mynd i'r dre heddiw?'' – 'Are you going to town today?' # Used with the indirect object (giving something to somebody). Note that English can (and often does) omit this preposition but Welsh always requires ''i''. ## ''Roddes i'r llyfr i Fred'' – 'I gave the book to Fred' ## ''Elli di ddangos hwnna i mi am eilliad?'' – 'Can you show me that a moment?' # Equates to English 'to' with the sense of 'purpose' or 'in order to' when followed by a verbal-noun: ## ''Fe adawodd y ddwy onyn nhw'n gynnar i ddal y bws'' – 'They both left early to catch the bus' ## ''Ddaethon ni â'r pris lawr i ddenu mwy o bobol'' – 'We brought the price down to attract more people'
    In this sense the compound preposition ''er mwyn'' 'in order to' is often used as an alternative: ''... er mwyn dal y bws...'' and ''...er mwyn denu mwy o bobol'' etc. Other common uses for ''i'' which do not correspond to 'to': # English 'for' ## ''Mae gen i lythyron i chi'' – 'I've got some letters for you' ## ''Nes i'r holl waith paratoi i ti bore 'ma'' – 'I did all the preparation for you this morning' ## ''Arhoswch funud - na i llnau nhw i chi'' – 'Wait a minute - I'll clean them for you' [''llnau'' is a colloquial contracted form of ''glanhau'' 'to clean'] # ''I'' can denote possession – especially when ''gyda/gan'' is not possible due to the nature of the sentence: ## ''Mae'r bobol 'na'n ffrindiau i mi'' – 'Those people are friends of mine' [lit. 'friends to me'] # Used after verbs of making or causing: ## ''Paid gwneud i Eleri chwerthin wrth iddi fwyta'' – 'Don't make Eleri laugh while she is eating' ## ''Yr unig esboniad a roddwyd oedd mai taro rhewfryn a achosodd iddi suddo'' – 'The only explanation given was that it was hitting an iceberg that caused her to sink' # Used after conjunctions (usually of time) to introduce the subject: ## ''...cyn i mi fynd'' – '...before I go' ## ''...er mwyn iddo ddeall'' – 'so that he can/could understand' # Means 'that' in past tense sentences + subject + verbal-noun: ## ''Dw i'n eitha siwr iddi ffonio rywbryd ddoe'' – 'I'm pretty sure (that) she phoned some time yesterday' When 'i' follows a verb its meaning usually parallels English but it should be noted that the English preposition can often be omitted. It should also be noted that ''gofyn'' 'ask' must also take ''i'' which may be unexpected by English speakers. # ''Gofynnwch iddo fo ydy o'n dod'' – 'Ask him if he is coming' [lit. 'ask to him...'] # ''Efallai y byddwch chi eisiau gofyn i'r plant am eu syniadau nhw'' – 'Perhaps you will want to ask the children for their ideas' The idiom ''rhoi gwybod i'' means 'inform' or 'let..... know': # ''Rhowch wybod i mi os glywch chi rywbeth'' – 'Let me know if you hear anything' The idiom ''yn dal i'' is used to mean 'still ....ing': # ''Mae Seren yn dal i deimlo'n sâl'' – 'Seren is still feeling ill' # ''Mae'n dal i fwrw'' – 'It's still raining' Even though ''i'' can cover 'into' (''i'r tŷ'' '(in)to the house'; ''i Gymru'' '(in)to Wales' etc.) the expanded form ''i mewn i'' (and rarely ''i fewn i'') can be used where this is the central idea or where it is emphasised: # ''Drychon ni o amgylch yr ardd, wedyn mynd i mewn i'r tŷ ei hun'' – 'We had a look around the garden, then we went into the house itself' '''Inflected forms of ''i''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''i'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|i mi, imi; i fi}} | {{lang|cy|i ni, inni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|i ti}} | {{lang|cy|i chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|iddo fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|iddyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|iddi hi}} |} Notes: # ''i mi'' and ''i fi'' are interchangeable but ''i fi'' is much more common in the South. # An older form of the 2nd pers. pl. ''iwch'' is still heard in the expression ''Nos dawch!, 'sdawch!'' 'Good night!' (contraction of ''nos da iwch'' 'good night to you') and is heard in the North. ===Mewn=== ''Mewn'' does not cause mutation and should not be confused with ''i mewn''. It means 'in' but is only used where the following noun is non-specific. Specific nouns require the use of ''yn''. Compare: # ''mewn tŷ'' – 'in a house'; but ''yn y tŷ'' – 'in the house' # ''mewn ardaloedd gwledig'' – 'in rural areas'; but ''yn yr ardaloedd gwledig'' – 'in the rural areas' # ''mewn gwladwriaeth ddemocrataidd'' – 'in a democratic state'; but ''yn Israel'' – 'in Israel' # ''mewn gwlad estron'' – 'in a foreign country'; but ''yn Lloegr'' – 'in England' ''Mewn'' does not have inflected forms. ===O=== ''O'' causes soft mutation. It equates to English 'from' and 'of', but care must be taken – ''o'' cannot be used for genitive constructions (those showing possession) for which Welsh has a specific method of constructing. ''O'' has the following meanings: # 'From' in most English senses, whether motion is implied or not. ## ''Dw i'n dod o Fangor yn wreiddiol'' – 'I come from Bangor originally' ## ''O Lanfairpwll ar Ynys Môn mae'r gantores Elin Fflur yn dod'' – 'The singer Elin Fflur comes from Llanfairpwll on Anglesey' ## ''Mae mrawd i'n llogi tŷ yn Nyfnaint o fis Mehefin tan fis Medi'' – 'My brother's renting a house in Devon from June to September' # 'Of' in quantity expressions or where part of something is implied ## ''Wi'n moyn hanner pwys o gaws a dwy botel o laeth'' – 'I want half a pound of cheese and two bottles of milk' # ''O'' can also be used with verbal-nouns: ## ''O ystyreid mai dyma'r tro cynta iddo siarad yn gyhoeddus, mae'n edrych yn hyderus iawn'' – 'Considering (or: When you consider...) that this is the first time he's spoken in public, he looks very confident' [lit. 'From considering...'] ## ''O'n i'n mynd i fod yn grac, ond o siarad â nhw mae'n amlwg fod 'na ryw gamddealltwriaeth wedi bod yn rhywle'' – 'I was going to be cross, but (after) speaking to them it's clear that there's been some misunderstanding somewhere' [lit. '..., but from speaking...'] # ''O'' can convey adverbial '-ly' where it qualifies and adjective – ''arbennig o dda'' 'especially good', ''hynod o galed'' 'extraordinarily hard' '''Inflected forms of ''o''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''o'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|ona i}} | {{lang|cy|onon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|onat ti}} | {{lang|cy|onoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|ono fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|onyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|oni hi}} |} Notes: # Variants ''ono i'' and ''onot ti'' are common. # Extended variants adding ''-ho-'' are also used (these are, strictly speaking, more "correct" forms, but they are usually not encountered in rapid speech), so ''ohonoch chi'' = ''onoch chi'' etc. These extended forms also more like the literary standard forms with the exceptions of 1st pers. sing. and 3rd pers. pl. # A negative variant ''mo'' is also in use and is a contraction of ''dim o''. This can be heard as ''monoch chi'' = ''dim ohonoch chi''. ===Oddiar=== ''Oddiar'' (also seen as ''oddi ar'') causes soft mutation and is a compound of ''o'' + ''ar'' (with ''o'' in its 3rd pers. sing. fem. form). ''Oddiar'' also takes the same inflections as ''ar'', e.g. ''oddiarno fo''. It is basically the opposite of ''ar'' and describes motion in the opposite direction of ''ar''. It therefore means 'off' in the sense of 'from upon': ''Cymer dy bethau oddiar y bwrdd, nei di?'' 'Take your things off the table, will you?'. ''Oddiar'' is not used to translate adverbial use of English 'off' ('turn off the TV', 'buzz off'), for which Welsh uses ''i ffwrdd'' (North) and ''bant'' (South). '''Inflected forms of ''oddiar''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''oddiar'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|oddiarna i}} | {{lang|cy|oddiarnon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|oddiarnat ti}} | {{lang|cy|oddiarnoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|oddiarno fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|oddiarnyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|oddiarni hi}} |} ===Oddiwrth=== ''Oddiwrth'' (also ''oddi wrth'') causes soft mutation and is a compound of ''o'' + ''wrth'' (with ''o'' in its 3rd pers. sing. fem. form). ''Oddiwrth'' inflects in the same way as ''wrth'', so ''oddiwrthi hi'' etc. It means 'from' but is restricted to sentiments sent from one person to another – the opposite of ''at'': ''Gaethon ni ddim cerdyn oddiwrth dy reini eleni, naddo?'' 'We didn't get a card from your parents this year, did we?; or ''Penblwydd Hapus oddiwrth bawb yn y swyddfa'' 'Happy Birthday from everyone at the office'. Where a verb of receiving (like ''cael'') is used – as in the first example above, ''gan'' is a possible alternative to ''oddiwrth''. '''Inflected forms of ''oddiwrth''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''oddiwrth'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|oddiwrtha i}} | {{lang|cy|oddiwrthon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|oddiwrthat ti}} | {{lang|cy|oddiwrthoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|oddiwrtho fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|oddiwrthyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|oddiwrthi hi}} |} ===Rhag=== ''Rhag'' is a lesser used preposition in colloquial Welsh and its usage is very restricted. ''Rhag'' causes no mutations and has the following meanings: # 'from' but only after certain verbs, like ''atal'' 'stop', ''rhwystro'' 'prevent', ''gwahardd'' 'forbid, prohibit': ## ''Bydd rhaid ceisio atal y bobol 'ma rhag dod yn rhy agos'' – 'We'll have to try to stop these people from coming too close'' ## ''Dw i am rwystro chi rhag niweidio'ch hunan'' – 'I want to try to prevent you (from) hurting yourself' ## ''Fe waharddwyd y teithwyr rhag mynd ymhellach'' – 'The travellers were forbidden to go any further' # ''Rhag'' is used as part of the conjunction ''rhag ofn'' 'in case, for fear that...': ## ''Dere di ag un yfory hefyd, rhag ofn i mi anghofio'' – 'You bring one tomorrow too, in case I forget' # It can appear in set expressions such as ''rhag cywilydd!'' 'for shame!', which is a less common version of ''cywilydd arant ti!'' (or ''arnoch chi!'') 'shame on you!' As a prefix, ''rhag-'' usually equates to English 'pre-' or 'fore-': ''rhagfarn'' 'prejudice', ''rhagweld'' 'foresee'. '''Inflected forms of ''rhag''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''rhag'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|rhagdda i}} | {{lang|cy|rhagddon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|rhagddat ti}} | {{lang|cy|rhagddoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|rhagddo fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|rhagddyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|rhagddi hi}} |} Note that these inflected forms are often pronounced as ''rhactha i, rhacthat ti, rhacthi hi'' etc. ===Rhwng=== ''Rhwng'', which causes no mutation, means 'between' and its usage is more-or-less the same as its English equivalent. Examples: # ''Bydd y gêm rhwng Cymru a Lloegr yn cael ei haildrefnu'' 'The game between Wales and England will be rescheduled'. # ''Dewch draw rywbryd rhwng tri a pedwar'' 'come around between three and four'' Inflected forms of ''rhwng'' (which has the stem ''rhyng-'') are used to make idiomatic expressions like ''Rhyngddat ti a fi...'' and ''Rhyngddoch chi a fi...'' 'Between you and me...'. '''Inflected forms of ''rhwng''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''rhwng'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|rhyngdda i}} | {{lang|cy|rhyngddon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|rhyngddat ti}} | {{lang|cy|rhyngddoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|rhyngddo fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|rhyngddyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|rhyngddi hi}} |} Note that these are often heard as ''rhyngtha i, rhyngthat ti'' etc. Also, variants using the stems ''rhwngdd-, rhynth-'' and ''rhyng-'' are in use. ===Tan=== ''Tan'', which causes soft mutation, means 'until, till' and is found with time expressions: # ''Fyddwn ni ffwrdd tan fis Tachwedd'' – 'We'll be away till November' # '''Dda i 'ma tan hanner awr wedi pedwar'' – 'I'll be here until quarter past four' ''Tan'' can also be used when taking leave of someone: ''Tan yfory 'te!'' 'Till tomorrow, then!', ''Tan hynny!'' 'Till then!', ''Tan y tro nesa!'' 'Till the next time!', ''Tan Ddydd Llun!'' 'Till Monday!' etc. Where English 'until' is used as a conjunction, that is when it is followed by a whole phrase with a verb in it, then ''nes'' is the preferred translation: # ''Na i aros tan ar ôl cinio'' – 'I'll wait until after lunch' # ''Na i aros nes iddo ffonio'' – 'I'll wait until he phones' However, ''tan'' can be heard to be used as a conjunction in some areas, so it is possible to hear (and therefore say) ''Na i aros tan iddo ffonio''; but there are also speakers who would consider this to be substandard or "bad Welsh". ''Tan'' has no inflected forms. ===Trwy=== ''Trwy'' (also ''trw'' and ''drwy''), which causes soft mutation, means 'through' in the spatial sense, e.g. ''cyllell boeth trwy fenyn'' 'a hot knife through butter', ''edrych trwy'r twll'' 'look through the hole'. ''Trwy'' also has other uses: # When used with a verbal-noun, it equates to English 'by (means of)... ing': ## ''Ceisiwch ymlacio trwy anadlu'n ddwfn am funud neu ddau'' – 'Try and relax by breathing deeply for a minute or two' ## ''Fedrwn ni ennill trwy ganolbwyntio'n fwy ar dactegau'' – 'We can win by concentrating more on tactics' # When used with time expressions it means 'all' (not 'every' which is ''bob'' (< ''pob'')): ## ''trwy'r dydd'' – 'all day'
    (''bob dydd'' – 'every day') ## ''trwy'r wythnos'' – 'all week' ## ''trwy'r flwyddyn'' – 'all year'
    In this sense ''gydol'' is sometimes heard with ''trwy'': ''trwy gydol y flwyddyn' 'all year' etc. '''Inflected forms of ''trwy''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''trwy'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|trwydda i}} | {{lang|cy|trwyddon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|trwyddat ti}} | {{lang|cy|trwyddoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|trwyddo fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|trwyddyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|trwyddi hi}} |} ===Tua / tuag=== ''Tua'' (''tuag'' before vowels) causes the aspirate mutation and means 'towards' in a spatial sense, but this meaning has been taken over by ''tuag at'' in the modern language, except for set expressions like ''tuag adre'' 'home(wards)'. Its primary use in the modern colloquial language is for conveying approximation. For example, 'about' with both time and quantity expressions: ''tua naw o'r gloch'' '(at) about nine o'clock', ''tua pum pwys o datws'' 'about five pounds of potatoes'. With expressions of time ''tua/tuag'' can be replaced with the compound preposition ''o gwmpas'': ''o gwmpas naw o'r gloch''. Some examples of the use of ''tua/tuag'': # ''Mae tua hanner y boblogaeth leol wedi ffoi'' – 'About half the local population have fled' # ''Mae e tua'r un fath fel arfer'' – 'It's usually about the same' ''Tua/tuag'' has no inflected forms. ===Wrth=== ''Wrth'' causes soft mutation and is almost always heard as ''wth'' in normal speech has a number of uses: # In purely spatial expressions ''wrth'' means 'by' or 'at' where there is a sense of close proximity: ## ''Wrth y ddesg'' – 'By the desk' ## ''Mae rhywun wrth y drws'' – 'Someone is at the door' # It also means 'by' when used after verbs of knowing or recognising: ## ''Nes i adnabod ti wrth dy ffordd o gerdded'' – 'I recognised you by the way you walk' # After ''dweud ('' or ''deud)'' 'say, tell' and other similar verbs: ## ''Beth yn union wedest ti wrth y ferch druan?'' – 'What exactly did you tell the poor girl?' # When used with a verbal-noun, ''wrth'' means 'while..... ing' and refers the action back to the subject: ## ''Pwy welson ni wrth ddod allan o'r siop ond dy gyn-wraig!'' – 'Who did we see (while) coming out of the shop but your ex!' [i.e. we were the ones coming out from the shop] # ''Wrth'' means 'for' after ''rhaid'' 'need'. ''Rhaid wrth'' '..... is needed': ## ''Rhaid wrth gyfaddawdu mewn sefyllfaoedd felly'' – 'There is a need for compromise in such situations' ## ''Rhaid wrth gefnogaeth'' – '(We) need support; Support is needed' # ''Wrth (i)'' is also a conjunction 'as, while':{{cite book |last=King |first=Gareth |year=2016 |orig-year=1993 |chapter=Conjunctions |title=Modern Welsh – A Comprehensive Grammar |language=English |edition=Third |location=London and New York |publisher=Routledge |page=396 |isbn=978-1-138-82630-4}} ## ''Wrth i Iolo ddod allan, es i i mewn'' – 'As Iolo came out, I went in' # ''Wrth'' can form a compound preposition ''wrth ymyl'' 'beside'. '''Inflected forms of ''wrth''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''wrth'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|wrtha i}} | {{lang|cy|wrthon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|wrthat ti}} | {{lang|cy|wrthoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|wrtho fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|wrthyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|wrthi hi}} |} These inflected forms are routinely shortened to '''tha i, 'that ti'' etc. in speech in all parts of Wales, especially after forms of ''dweud/deud'': # ''Mae isio deud 'thyn nhw be' 'dy be', on'd oes?'' – 'They need telling what's what, don't they?' [Northern dialect] # ''Be' wedodd hi 'thoch chi?'' – 'What did she say to you?' Some idiomatic uses of ''wrth'': # ''Wrth'' + a possessive adjective + ''bodd'' means 'delighted' or 'in one's element': ## ''Dw i wrth 'y modd'' – 'I'm as happy as can be' ## ''Mae e wrth ei fodd'' – 'He's in his element' # The 3rd pers. sing. f. form ''wrthi'' is used with ''yn'' + a verbal-noun to mean 'busy..... ing': ## ''Mae'r plant i gyd wrthi'n codi castell tywod draw fan 'na'' – 'The kids are all busy building a sand castle over there' ===Yn=== ''Yn'' causes nasal mutation (though soft mutation is often heard instead) and means 'in'. ''Yn'' 'in' is a true preposition and must not be confused with the complement marker particle ''yn'' seen after the verb ''bod''. It is only used when a definite (specific) noun follows (c.f. ''mewn''). ''Yn'' is therefore often seen preceding the definite article or the names of places: ''yn y car'' 'in the car' or ''yn Llandudno'' 'in Llandudno'. Compare the difference between the use of ''yn'' and ''mewn'': ''yn yr ardd'' 'in the garden' (specific), but ''mewn gardd'' 'in a garden' (non-specific). '''Mutations after ''yn''''' ''Yn'' causes the nasal mutation, but it undergoes a change itself depending on what follows. Therefore ''yn'' often appears as ''ym'' and ''yng'', though ''ym'' only appears before a word beginning with 'm-' or 'mh-' and ''yng'' only appears before words beginning with 'ng-' or 'ngh-' whether this is the result of mutation or not: # ''ym Mangor'' – 'in Bangor' # ''yng Ngheredigion'' – 'in Ceredigion' # ''yn Nolgellau'' – 'in Dolgellau' # ''yng Ngogledd Cymru'' – 'in North Wales' # ''ym mhwllheli'' – 'in Pwllheli' # ''yn Nhalybont' – 'in Talybont' # ''ym Machynlleth'' - 'in Machynlleth'' # ''yn Llandudno'' – 'in Llandudno' # ''yn yr Alban'' – 'in Scotland' The examples above are all place-names, but the rule holds true for all words following ''yn''. For example, ''yng nghanol y dre'' 'in the middle of the town'. It should be noted, however, that mutation of place names not of Welsh origin (often English) is often avoided, but not always. The following are all possible in colloquial Welsh for 'in Camden' (an area of London): # ''yng Nghamden'' [Nasal mutation] # ''yn Gamden'' [Soft mutation] # ''yn Camden'' [no mutation] It should also be noted that 'in Welsh' is always ''yn Gymraeg'', even in the literary language and is never ''*yng Nghymraeg''; it is sometimes heard as ''yn y Gymraeg'', it is because of this definite article being omitted that ''yn Gymraeg'' is used and not ''*yng Nghymraeg''. '''Inflected forms of ''yn''''' The table below gives the inflected forms of ''yn'' with their accompanying pronouns: :{| class="wikitable" |- style="background: #efefef;" | colspan="2" | ! scope="col" | Singular ! scope="col" | Plural |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | First Person | {{lang|cy|yndda i}} | {{lang|cy|ynddon ni}} |- ! colspan="2" scope="row" | Second Person | {{lang|cy|ynddat ti}} | {{lang|cy|ynddoch chi}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | Third Person ! scope="row" | Masculine | {{lang|cy|ynddo fe/fo}} | rowspan="2" | {{lang|cy|ynddyn nhw}} |- ! scope="row" | Feminine | {{lang|cy|ynddi hi}} |} Note that variants with ''-d-'' are often heard instead of ''-dd-'': ''ynda i, yndo fe'' etc., as are variants with no linking element: ''yna i, yno fe'' etc. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Welsh linguistics}} [[Category:Welsh grammar]] [[Category:Parts of speech]] [[Category:Syntax]]

page.title: Commissioner for Older People for Northern Ireland

revision.text:
{{notability|date=August 2013}} The '''Commissioner for Older People for Northern Ireland''' is set up as a non-departmental public body, established by the Commissioner for Older People Act (Northern Ireland) 2011. The Commissioner has a number of legal functions and powers directly linked to the legislation. The Commissioner's office is sponsored by the [[Executive Office (Northern Ireland)|Executive Office]] of [[Northern Ireland]]. The Commissioner is independent and the principal aim of her office is to safeguard and promote the interests of older people. The current Commissioner for Older People for Northern Ireland is Eddie Lynch.
== Key duties ==
The Commissioner's key duties are: # To promote awareness of the interests of older people in Northern Ireland. # To keep under review the adequacy and effectiveness of the law as it affects older people. # To keep under review the adequacy and effectiveness of services provided to older people by "relevant authorities" who include health and social care providers. # To promote the provision of opportunities for and the elimination of discrimination against older people. # To encourage best practice in the treatment of older people. # To promote positive attitudes towards older people and encourage participation by older people in public life. # To advise the Assembly, the Secretary of State and any relevant authority on matters concerning the interests of older people. # To take reasonable steps to communicate with older people.
==The Commissioner's general powers== The law states that the Commissioner may: * Make arrangements for research or educational activities concerning the interests of older people. * Issue guidance on best practice in relation to any matter concerning the interests of older people. * Conduct investigations for the purpose of any of her functions. * Compile and publish information concerning the interests of older people. * Provide advice or information on any matter concerning the interests of older people.
== References ==
* https://web.archive.org/web/20130602111201/http://www.northernireland.gov.uk/index/media-centre/news-departments/news-ofmdfm/news-archive-ofmdfm-october-2011/news-ofmdfm-031011-first-commissioner-for.htm * http://www.ageuk.org.uk/northern-ireland/latest-news/archive/commissioner-for-older-peolpe-ni/ * https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-22389786
== External links ==
* {{official website|http://www.copni.org/|COPNI.org}} * [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/nisr/2012/388/made Commissioner for Older People Act 2011(Commencement) Order (Northern Ireland) 2012]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox dot-com company | name = Cupid plc | logo = Cupid plc logo new.png | company_type = [[public limited company|plc]] | traded_as = {{LSE|CUP}} | foundation = | dissolved = | location = Edinburgh, Scotland | locations = | incorporated = | area_served = Worldwide | founder = | chairman = | chairperson = | president = | CEO = | MD = | GM = | key_people = Bill Dobbie, co-founder & CEO
Max Polyakov, co-Founder (no longer involved with the company)
Niall Stirling, CFO and Company Secretary | industry = [[Online dating]] | products = Cupid.com, Flirt.com, BeNaughty.com, other | services = | revenue = £53.6M (2011){{citation needed|date=June 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cupidplc.com/investors/investor-relations-and-downloads?download=76:annual-report-for-year-ended-31-dec-2011|title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=8 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510101328/http://www.cupidplc.com/investors/investor-relations-and-downloads?download=76%3Aannual-report-for-year-ended-31-dec-2011 |archivedate=10 May 2012 |df=dmy }} | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 500 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | company_slogan = | programming_language = | ipv6 = | alexa = | website_type = | advertising = | registration = | num_users = 54 million (June 2012) | language = English, French, German, Portuguese, Spanish, Swedish, other | launch_date = | current_status = inactive | screenshot = | caption = | footnotes = | intl = | url = {{URL|http://www.cupidplc.com/}}{{broken link|date=June 2018}} }} '''Cupid plc''' was the owner and operator of multiple high-volume [[online dating]] websites, covering the range from mainstream to niche audiences. The full network of websites is available worldwide in a variety of languages, and by the end of the first half of 2012 more than 54 million users had created profiles in the company's websites.{{cite web |title=Online Dating Leader Cupid Sees Members Increase Six-Fold During First Half of 2012 |url=http://www.virtual-strategy.com/2012/06/20/online-dating-leader-cupid-sees-members-increase-six-fold-during-first-half-2012 |publisher=PRWeb |accessdate=13 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415084805/http://www.virtual-strategy.com/2012/06/20/online-dating-leader-cupid-sees-members-increase-six-fold-during-first-half-2012 |archivedate=15 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }} As is customary among all internet dating companies, all of their products are available across multiple devices (web, mobile, [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]]) and platforms (on [[web browsers]], within [[Facebook Platform|Facebook]]). ==History== Founded in 2005 by Bill Dobbie and Max Polyakov, the company was originally made up of a range of dating websites operated from and off-shore base. In 2006, Polyakov and Dobbie acquired the EasyDate business and brand to complement and serve as an umbrella for their network of sites, which had been experiencing a steady growth in user base. The company quickly grew its user base – by 2007 they had their first million paying users, and a few years after that they hit an impressive 13 million paying users across all networks. By early March 2010, the user base was growing at a rate of 300,000 per month, and new products were succeeding in increasing these numbers and expanding the user base. A year later, in May 2011, the company boasted 23 million members in 39 countries.{{cite web |last=Ashcroft |first=Jamie |title=Cupid Plc says it's beating market expectations as online dating gains credibility |url=http://www.proactiveinvestors.co.uk/companies/news/28629/cupid-plc-says-its-beating-market-expectations-as-online-dating-gains-credibility-28629.html |publisher=ProActive Investors UK |accessdate=14 November 2012}} The company was named as Scotland's fastest growing technology firm by [[Deloitte]] in its October 2011 Fast 500 listing,{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-15341387 |title=BBC News - Cupid named Scotland's fastest-growing technology firm |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=17 October 2011 |accessdate=6 July 2012}} and in May 2012, went on to be awarded the UK Stock Market Awards 2012 award for Best Travel & Leisure PLC.{{cite web |url=http://www.stockmarketawards.com/winners/ |title=Winners | Stock Market Awards 2012 |publisher=Stockmarketawards.com |accessdate=6 July 2012}} This success, and the desire to fund further growth, prompted the company to become listed in the [[Alternative Investment Market]] of the [[London Stock Exchange]] (AIM). Upon admission, the company had an approximate market capitalisation of £45 million. The fresh capital brought about by the listing enabled the company to perform some strategic acquisitions in markets where it had detected potential, like France, Germany, the US, and Brazil. On 24 July 2012, Cupid plc announced that it had acquired the French dating site Assistance Genie Logiciel (AGL) for the sum of €3.7 million.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-18969004 |title=Cupid finds amour with French acquisition |publisher=BBC |accessdate=24 July 2012}} The deal to buy the 1986-founded company includes French dating sites amour.com, serencontrer.com and ulla.com. Also in 2012 Cupid acquired Uniform Dating, a niche website aimed at uniformed services personnel such as firefighters, nurses, armed forces and police.{{cite news |title=Online dating firm Cupid buys uniform dating site |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-19597698 |newspaper=BBC News |date=14 September 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2012}} ===BBC investigation=== In February 2013, the company was the subject of [[BBC Radio 5 Live|BBC Radio 5live Investigates]] programme. Users told the BBC that they had received many messages from potential dates as free users of the site but that, when they paid for membership to be able to reply, the volume of messages dramatically decreased.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21366326|title=Online dating firm denies creating profiles to tempt clients |publisher=BBC News |date=24 February 2013 |accessdate=22 March 2013}} The company denied that it was sending the messages to entice users to pay for membership and has commissioned an independent audit into its operation.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-21904616 |title=Online dating firm Cupid plc sees share value plunge |publisher=BBC News |date=22 February 2013 |accessdate=22 March 2013}} After a subsequent investigation into these claims, one of the sources of the accusations made a public apology regarding factual inaccuracies in his blog postings on the subject.{{cite web |url=http://brontecapital.blogspot.co.uk/2013/04/apology-to-cupid-plc.html |title=Source' apology to Cupid Plc |publisher=John Hempton |date=8 April 2013 |accessdate=5 June 2013}} Investigation by Ukrainian newspaper Kyivpost in March 2013 proved usage of fake profiles by the company and confirmed that the company's 'social media managers', whose job was to tempt users, were actually located in Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/article/content/ukraine/deceptive-love-agency-hires-women-to-encourage-men-to-pay-321741.html|title=Deceptive Love: Agency hires women to encourage men to pay|publisher=Kyivpost}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-23409947|title=Concerns raised over web dating 'fake profiles'|publisher=BBC News}} It was revealed that only about 20 employers of Cupid plc actually worked in the United Kingdom, and around 1500 staff members were located in Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/544/147999.html|title=The insecurity of today's internet|publisher=Bizcommunity}} The company stated that its auditors KPMG had found 'no evidence of a company organised practice of staff enticing registered members to subscribe through the use of fake profiles'. Nevertheless, Cupid recognized that existing staff profiles 'were not clearly identifiable' to users and said it had replaced the motivation teams with dating advisors. In July 2013, BBC published new investigation, claiming that problem of fake profiles still existed, and the company used real persons' data without their knowledge.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-23425366|title='I'm used to playing different people, but with my consent'|publisher=BBC News}} Such kind of semi-legal activities is a subject to legal prosecution in some countries. Björn and Benjamin Bak, founders of German dating application Lovoo, and twelve members of their staff were arrested and accused of commercial deception because of using similar scheme.{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.de/20160608/police-arrest-founders-of-popular-berlin-dating-app-lovoo|title=Police raid premises of popular Berlin dating app|publisher=The Local}} [[Avid Life Media]], founder of dating site AshleyMadison.com, was accused of using 'fembots' on a large scale.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/ashley-madison-admits-tricking-men-with-fake-fembots/|title=Ashley Madison admits tricking men with fake fembots|publisher=The Telegraph}} British-based JDI Dating Ltd was fined by US Federal Trade Commission for using fake profiles.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2815488/Dating-website-fined-using-fake-computer-generated-profiles-trick-users-spending-paid-memberships.html|title=Dating website fined for using fake computer-generated profiles to trick users into spending more on paid memberships|publisher=Daily Mail}} ==Business and products== Cupid's business can be split into two main areas: [[mainstream]] dating websites, aimed at the general public with some level of differentiation between them (for example, Cupid.com is aimed at people looking for a steady partner in a more long-term relationship, whereas BeNaughty.com is geared towards users looking for more [[casual relationship|casual dating]]); and niche websites, where the whole concept fundamentally hinges on the users looking for partners of a similar background and tastes. The [[business model]] varies slightly depending on the website. In most cases, users can join for free – this gives them access to the website and allows them to browse the profiles of other users. Once they are ready to begin interacting with someone, the website charges depending on the level of access the user wants. This is a fairly common practice across the industry. Cupid makes most of their business through the charging of these fees, as there is no advertising on their websites. In addition to this, Cupid also partners with other companies in order to provide a branded, specifically targeted [[online dating]] experience. Cupid plc disposed of its casual dating sites in July 2013. It sold the remaining mainstream dating sites to [[NSI Holdings Ltd]]. in December 2014 and is no longer involved in online dating. ==Name change== The company had been trading as EasyDate since 2006, when it acquired the name. Because of this, it was under that name that it became initially listed in the markets (as EasyDate plc). However, in December 2010, as a result of pressure from [[easyGroup]] founder Sir [[Stelios Haji-Ioannou]], the company changed its name.{{cite news |last=Clark |first=Nick |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/sir-stelioss-arrows-turn-easydate-into-cupid-2159694.html |title=Sir Stelios's arrows turn EasyDate into Cupid |publisher=The Independent |date=14 December 2010 |accessdate=6 July 2012}} The name Cupid plc was chosen as it had been acquired in September of that year, along with all associated domains for £4.4 million.{{cite news |last=Scuffham|first=Matt |title=EasyDate buys Cupid.com to kick off expansion |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/09/22/easydate-idUSLDE68L08820100922 |accessdate=14 November 2012 |newspaper=Reuters |date=22 September 2010}} ==End of Cupid plc== The investigations by BBC and Kyivpost caused a sharp decline in the share prices. In Summer 2013, the company sold part of its 'casual dating business' to Grendall Investment Limited, controlled by co-founder and shareholder of Cupid plc Max Polyakov.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-scotland-business-23319313 |title=Cupid plc sells 'casual dating business' for £45.1m |publisher=BBC News}} In 2014, Cupid plc suffered heavy losses and was forced to call in part of money owed by Grendall. The company preferred to take a reduced £12,5 million instead of around £20 million to get it a year earlier. Late Cupid plc announced that it sold final dating businesses for just £3 million.{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/tinder-breaks-cupids-heart-as-firm-completes-sale-of-dating-businesses-at-massive-discount-9910363.html |title=Tinder breaks Cupid's heart as firm completes sale of dating businesses at massive discount|publisher=Independent}}{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/analysis-and-features/how-tinder-shot-down-cupid-9911664.html |title=How Tinder shot down Cupid |publisher=Independent}} It is believed that assets were bought by the companies connected to Max Polyakov. Cupid pls was renamed Castle Street Investment and realigned as an investment company. ==See also== * [[Cupid.com]] * [[Badoo]] * [[eHarmony]] * [[Cupid Media]] * [[HitDynamics]], another company founded by Max Polyakov * [[Match.com]] * [[Zoosk]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.onlinepersonalswatch.com/news/2013/09/quickie-interview-phil-gripton-ceo-of-cupidcom.html] OPW - Interwiev with Cupid Ceo Phil Gripton, 19 September 2013] [[Category:Online dating services]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:Dating]] [[Category:Intimate relationships]] [[Category:Matchmaking]] [[Category:Social media]] [[Category:Social software|Dating service]]

{{BLP refimprove|date=January 2013}} '''Daniel Kolak''' (born 1955 in [[Zagreb]], [[Socialist Republic of Croatia|Croatia]]) is a [[Croatia]]n-American [[philosopher]] who works primarily in [[philosophy of mind]], [[personal identity]], [[cognitive science]], [[philosophy of science]], [[philosophy of mathematics]], [[philosophy of logic]], [[philosophy of religion]], and [[aesthetics]]. He is professor of philosophy at the [[William Paterson University]] of New Jersey and an Affiliate of the Rutgers University Center for Cognitive Science (RuCCS). Kolak is the founder of the philosophical therapy known as [[cognitive dynamics]].
==Biography==
Kolak is a prolific philosopher, with over thirty-five authored books and nearly two hundred books edited.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpunj.edu/cohss/departments/philosophy/faculty/daniel-kolak.dot|title=Dr. Daniel Kolak|work=wpunj.edu}}</ref> He is professor of philosophy at the [[William Paterson University of New Jersey]] (WPUNJ), where he chaired the Philosophy Department and founded and directed the [http://www.wpunj.edu/cohss/departments/philosophy/the-philosophy-program/cogsci/ WPUNJ cognitive science laboratory]. He also directs research at the Brain Behavior Center and is an affiliate of [[Rutgers University]]'s [https://web.archive.org/web/20080509135833/http://ruccs.rutgers.edu/ruccs/ Center for Cognitive Science (RuCCS)]. Kolak's numerous articles, stories, essays, books and other creative works bridge traditional philosophy with all areas of inquiry and expression, from neuroscience to quantum mechanics, from logic and mathematics to art, music and literature. Among his best known recent works are ''I Am You: The Metaphysical Foundations for Global Ethics'', ''Principles of Cognitive Science'', ''[[Wittgenstein]]'s Tractatus'', ''Wisdom Without Answers'', ''From the Presocratics to the Present'', ''In Search of God: The Language and Logic of Belief'', ''The Experience of Philosophy'', ''Self, Cosmos, God'', ''Self and Identity'', and the novel ''In Search of Myself: Life, Death and Personal Identity''. He is editor, chief programmer and designer of the interactive electronic library ''The Philosophy Source'' on CD-ROM, and was Series Editor of the Wadsworth Philosopher Series and Philosophical Topics. As Series Editor at Longman, he is currently bringing out new editions of the complete canon of philosophy from ancient times to the present. Translated into over a dozen languages, collectively his books have sold over a million copies worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.croatia.org/crown/articles/8910/1/Famous-Croatian-American-Philosopher-Prof-Dr-Daniel-Kolak.html|title=Famous Croatian American Philosopher Prof. Dr. Daniel Kolak|work=croatia.org}}</ref>
Kolak is the originator of the philosophy known as [[Open individualism|Open Individualism]], which he developed along with his view of metaphysical subjectivism and the nonlocality of consciousness, according to which there exists but one numerically identical individual subject who is everyone. In his groundbreaking ''I Am You: the Metaphysical Foundations for Global Ethics'', he writes: "The central thesis of ''I Am You'' - that we are all the same person - is apt to strike many readers as obviously false or even absurd. How could you be me and Hitler and Gandhi and Jesus and Buddha and Greta Garbo and everybody else in the past, present and future? In this book I explain how this is possible. Moreover, I show that this is the best explanation of who we are for a variety of reasons, not the least of which is that it provides the metaphysical foundations for global ethics." Variations on Kolak's theme have been voiced periodically throughout the ages (the [[Upanishads]], [[Averroes]], [[Giordano Bruno]], [[Arthur Schopenhauer|Schopenhauer]], [[Josiah Royce]]); more recently, physicists such as [[Erwin Schrödinger]], [[Fred Hoyle]], and [[Freeman Dyson]] have espoused it.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kolak|first1=Daniel|title=I Am You: The Metaphysical Foundations for Global Ethics. (Volume 25 of the Synthese Library: Studies in Epistemology, Logic, Methodology, and Philosophy of Science.)|date=2004|publisher=Synthese Library, Springer|location=Dordrecht, the Netherlands|isbn=1-4020-2999-3}}</ref>
Kolak continues to work on the logical foundations of quantum mechanics and a mathematical model of consciousness (e.g. Stone-Čech compactification) that integrates relativity and quantum mechanics using an "Ultra-Strong (Open World) Nonlocality" variation on a (spinning, with closed timelike paths) Gödel universe, and other such foundational issues in mathematics, physics and logic further refined with Jaakko Hintikka's IF ([[Independence-friendly logic|Independence-Friendly]]) and [[epistemic logic]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Eklund|first1=Matti|last2=Kolak|first2=Daniel|title=Is Hintikka's Logic First-Order?|journal=Synthese|date=2002-06-01|volume=131|issue=3|pages=371-388|doi=10.1023/A:1016184410627|publisher=Kluwer Academic Publishers; Springer Netherlands|location=The Netherlands|issn=0039-7857}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kolak|first1=Daniel|last2=Symons|first2=John|editor1-last=Kolak|editor1-first=Daniel|editor2-last=Symons|editor2-first=John|title=Quantifiers, Questions, and Quantum Physics: Essays on the Philosophy of Jaakko Hintikka|date=2004|publisher=Springer|location=Dordrecht, The Netherlands|isbn=978-1-4020-3210-3|chapter=Forward and Acknowledgements (p. 1-2); The Results are in: The Scope and Import of Hintikka's Philosophy (p. 209-271)}}</ref> He has also made original contributions to the philosophy of religion, the history of philosophy, and the teaching of philosophy.
Kolak is the founder of the philosophical therapy known as cognitive dynamics, which has been used to create new paradigms and technologies for expanding human consciousness, increasing intelligence, and improving creativity. It is still under development. More information about this aspect of Kolak's research in cognitive science (cognitive neuroscience; self-representation; information processing; knowledge representation; mental models; the logic and mathematics of mental processes; autism, confabulation, self-deception, MPD; dreaming), philosophy of mind (personal identity, consciousness, and self; philosophical psychology; psychoanalytic theory) can be found at the [http://ruccs.rutgers.edu/ruccs/index.php/people/affiliates Rutgers University Center for Cognitive Science (RuCCS)].
Kolak is an expert on dreams, particularly about how the brain synthesizes experience and creates the virtual world we call reality. His unique work on lucid dreams has recently been featured in a documentary, produced by NBC/Universal, which aired in November 2006.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Afterlife|journal=SCI FI Investigates [TV Show]|date=1 November 2006|volume=Season 1|issue=Episode 4|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0957186/?ref_=nm_flmg_slf_1|accessdate=23 July 2014}}</ref>
As a composer and musician he has performed in concert on numerous occasions, both solo and with leading musicians such as [[Charlie Byrd]], [[Dizzy Gillespie]] and [[Frank Zappa]]. As a theatrical director and composer he has won the coveted [[Helen Hayes]] Creativity Award for productions such as [[Sartre]]'s ''[[No Exit]]'' at the Source Theater in Washington, D.C. Among his film work is the teleplay ''Id-Entity'', about multiple personality disorder as seen through the eyes of four patients, which Kolak wrote, directed, and produced, and the score and soundtrack for ''Forsaken Cries: the Case of Rwanda'' which he produced for [[PBS]], by [[Amnesty International]] and narrated by [[Danny Glover]]. Most recently Kolak served as special advisor to [[Martin Scorsese]] in the making of the [[Academy Award]]-winning film ''[[The Departed]]''.
In the United States, Kolak successfully lobbied the U.S. government on behalf of the children and retirees of the [[United Nations]] and its sister institutions the IMF and [[World Bank]]. As president and co-founder of the [[G-4 Coalition]] in Washington, D.C., Kolak helped write a bill, sponsored by US Senator [[Ted Kennedy]], allowing the children and retirees of the IMF and World Bank to become permanent U.S. residents. He testified before Congress and worked together with former World Bank President [[Robert S. McNamara]] to lobby successfully for the bill's passage. For his efforts on behalf of the international community living in the United States, he received a personal commendation from the Secretary General of the United Nations.
